title: Linux Kernel Released
overview: Linus Torvalds announces the first release of the Linux kernel as a free Unix-like operating system, sparking a revolution in open-source software.

title: Slackware Linux
overview: Patrick Volkerding releases Slackware, one of the earliest Linux distributions, which remains active as the oldest maintained distro.

title: Debian Linux
overview: The Debian Project is founded by Ian Murdock, emphasizing free software principles and community governance.

title: Red Hat Linux
overview: Red Hat releases its Linux distribution, pioneering the enterprise support model and becoming a cornerstone of Linux in business.

title: SUSE Linux
overview: SUSE releases its Linux distribution in Germany, becoming a major European enterprise Linux provider.

title: Gentoo Linux
overview: Gentoo emerges as a source-based distribution focused on customization and performance tuning through its Portage system.

title: Arch Linux
overview: Arch Linux launches with a lightweight, rolling-release philosophy, later inspiring projects like Manjaro.

title: Fedora Linux
overview: Fedora Project is created as a community-driven, cutting-edge Linux distro sponsored by Red Hat, becoming a testing ground for enterprise features.

title: Ubuntu Linux
overview: Canonical launches Ubuntu, focused on usability and accessibility, quickly becoming one of the most popular Linux distros worldwide.

title: CentOS Linux
overview: CentOS is founded as a free rebuild of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, becoming a staple in hosting and enterprise environments.

title: openSUSE Linux
overview: Novell launches openSUSE, a community-driven project based on SUSE Linux, known for its YaST configuration tool.

title: Alpine Linux
overview: Alpine Linux is introduced as a lightweight, security-oriented distro, later becoming the backbone of many container environments.

title: Linux Mint
overview: Linux Mint is released, offering a user-friendly desktop experience with multimedia codecs pre-installed, popular among new Linux users.
